Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Vasopressin-mediated regulation of juvenile social behaviors
Award.AbstractNarration:
The neuropeptide arginine-vasopressin (AVP) is involved in the regulation of diverse social behaviors in adulthood. However, it is less clear how the AVP system in the brain regulates social behaviors during the juvenile period. This project will elucidate the mechanisms by which AVP regulates social play and social novelty-preference in juvenile male and female rats. Complementary approaches will be used, including microdialysis, pharmacological manipulations, and neuronal activation, to elucidate interactions between AVP and GABA systems in the lateral septum and AVP-mediated alterations in neuronal activation in projection areas of the lateral septum. The results will provide new insights on the regulation of social interactions among juveniles, which are known to be critically important for development of social competence and socialization in mammals, including rodents and humans.

The research will be integrated with an education plan in which new initiatives will be developed to expose high school and undergraduate students, particularly those from minority and under-represented groups, to hands-on behavioral neuroscience research. The research and education plans will build a firm foundation for a lifetime of integrated contributions to behavioral neuroscience research and education. Research findings will be disseminated to the public through public lectures, publications, and a web site. The archiving, access, and sharing of data will be according to Boston College policies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The neuropeptide arginine-vasopressin (AVP) is involved in the regulation of diverse social behaviors in adulthood. However, it is less clear how the AVP system in the brain regulates social behaviors during the juvenile period. This project demonstrated that AVP, as well as two other neuropeptides namely oxytocin and opioids, are important for the expression of juvenile social behaviors. It was shown that AVP interacts with glutamate and dopamine systems in the lateral septum to regulate juvenile social play behavior in sex-specific ways. It was also shown that oxytocin and opioids act in the nucleus accumbens to modulate the expression of juvenile social novelty seeking behavior. Finally, robust age and sex differences were observed in the AVP, oxytocin, and opioid receptor systems in the brain, thereby providing starting points to investigate the involvement of these neuropeptides in age- and sex-specific expression of social behaviors. Overall, these findings provide new insights into the regulation of juvenile social behaviors, which are known to be critically important for the development of social competence and socialization in mammals, including rodents and humans.

This research was integrated with an education plan in which new initiatives were developed to expose high school and undergraduate students to hands-on behavioral neuroscience research. The research and education plans built a firm foundation for a lifetime of integrated contributions to behavioral neuroscience research and education. New outreach efforts included the successful launch of the bring-your-parents-to-the-lab day. Research findings have been disseminated to the public through public lectures, conference presentations, peer-reviewed publications, and the lab website.
